tutorial.title: Weight Converter
tutorial.descriptionContent: Use arrow functions to optimize a kilogram to pounds converter

executableContent.instructions:
We'll now use our knowledge of arrow functions to create a kilograms to pounds converter.

The first variable will store the user's weight in kilograms. 

1. Create a const variable `kilograms` variable and give it a value `60`.

Next, we'll need another variable that stores an arrow function.

1. Declare a const variable `getPounds`.
2. Assign an arrow function to `getPounds` that has a parameter `kgs`.

hints.title: Arrow Function Styntax
hints.content: Make sure to include curly braces after the "fat arrow" of the arrow function.

executableContent.instructions:
The arrow function will then store the conversion outcome in a block-scoped variable.

1. Declare a const variable named `pounds` inside the curly braces of the arrow function.

files.name: script.js

executableContent.instructions:
To complete the conversion, one kilogram is about 2.20 pounds. 

1. Set the expression for multiplying `kgs` by `2.20` to the variable `pounds`.

files.name: script.js

executableContent.instructions:
The arrow function will return `pounds` when the conversion is complete and stored in the variable.

1. Have the arrow function `return` `pounds`. You can also call the function here to test it out if you choose to.

files.name: script.js

executableContent.instructions:
To shorten the code, we can refactor `getPounds` to have our expression on the same line. Doing so does not require curly brace syntax, the `pounds` variable, and a `return` keyword.

1. Remove the curly braces and the final semicolon.
2. Remove the `pounds` variable and `=` as they are not necessary. Don't remove the multiplication operation or the semicolon.
3. Remove the `return` statement, as the expression is implicitly returned in a one-line arrow function.
4. Place the entire syntax of the refactored function on a single line.

files.name: script.js

hints.title: One-line arrow function
hints.content: Make sure that the arrow function is composed of a single line. `const example = (var) => expression;`

executableContent.instructions:
Now that `getPounds` has been refactored, call the function and pass in an argument.

1. Call `getPounds`.
2. Pass in the variable `kilograms` as an argument.

files.name: script.js

executableContent.instructions:
Now it's time to display the converted weight in the console. 

1. Wrap `getPounds(kilograms)` with a  `console.log()` to display the value of pounds.
